item.title: Net Migration to UK Halves as Record Drop Boosts Starmer
item.description: Net migration to the UK tumbled nearly 50% to 431,000 last year, a record drop and a welcome development for Prime Minister Keir Starmer as he tries to win back voters attracted by Nigel Farage’s right-wing Reform party.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

item.title: Modi Rules Out Talks With Pakistan a Month After Kashmir Attacks
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi ruled out any talks with Islamabad, and vowed to make Pakistan’s economy and army pay for any aggression on Indian soil, as tensions between the South Asian neighbors remain high a month after deadly Kashmir attacks.
item.dc:creator: Swati Gupta

media:content.media:description: Narendra Modi

item.title: Pitfalls of an Oval Office Meeting With Trump
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump holds up a printed article from "American Thinker" while accusing South Africa's President Cyril Ramaphosa of state-sanctioned violence against white farmers in South Africa in the Oval Office at the White House on May 21. Photographer: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images

item.title: Fringe White Afrikaners Show How Lobbying Trump Can Work
item.description: The fringe group that planted the seed for some of Donald Trump’s false claims that South Africa is persecuting White farmers saw years of lobbying US politicians pay off.
item.dc:creator: Rene Vollgraaff

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump shows pictures as he meets with Cyril Ramaphosa in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on May 21.

item.title: Merz Says Germany Will Defend Against ‘Any Threat’ in Baltics
item.description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz said his military is prepared to defend the Baltic region against “any threat” as he arrived in Lithuania to mark the establishment of a battle tank brigade to bolster NATO’s eastern flank.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber, Milda Seputyte

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz and Gitanas Nauseda, left, during a welcoming ceremony in Vilnius, Lithuania, on May 22. Photographer: Paulius Peleckis/Getty Images

item.title: Two Israeli Embassy Staffers Killed in Washington Shooting
item.description: Two members of the Israeli embassy’s staff were killed outside the Capital Jewish Museum in Washington on Wednesday night by a gunman who chanted “Free, Free Palestine,” officials said, condemning the attack as an antisemitic hate crime.
item.dc:creator: Myles Miller, John Harney, Dan Williams

media:content.media:description: FBI agents cordon off the scene outside the Capital Jewish Museum following a shooting that left two people dead, in Washington, DC, on May 21. Photographer: Alex Wroblewski/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Thai Court Orders Ex-Premier Yingluck to Pay $306 Million Fine
item.description: A Thai court ordered former prime minister Yingluck Shinawatra to pay a 10.03 billion baht ($306 million) fine for losses incurred under her administration’s controversial rice purchase program over a decade ago.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Yingluck Shinawatra

item.title: Trump’s Ambush of Ramaphosa Leaves South Africa Reeling
item.description: South Africans watched aghast on Wednesday as US President Donald Trump berated their leader in the Oval Office over false claims that there’s a genocide against White people in the country.
item.dc:creator: Neil Munshi

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, holds news articles during a meeting with Cyril Ramaphosa, South Africa's president, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 21, 2025. Ramaphosa said "We are essentially here to reset the relationship between the United States and South Africa."

item.title: Portugal Opposes Further Increase in Spanish Banks’ Presence
item.description: Portugal said Spanish lenders shouldn’t further increase their presence in the country, the latest sign of a European government wanting to intervene in potential banking deals.
item.dc:creator: Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: Joaquim Miranda Sarmento Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: Moscow Faces Second Day of Drone Attacks, Disrupting Flights
item.description: Moscow is facing a second day of large-scale drone attacks, causing delays for dozens of flights with airports around the Russian capital forced to temporarily halt operations.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sills

media:content.media:description: The Kremlin, Moscow.

item.title: India Says Top Maoist Rebel Killed in ‘Major Breakthrough’
item.description: Indian security forces killed a top Maoist rebel leader, Home Affairs Minister Amit Shah said, calling it a “major breakthrough” in the nation’s decades-long fight against the left-wing extremism.
item.dc:creator: Swati Gupta

media:content.media:description: Amit Shah Photographer: Hindustan Times/Hindustan Times

item.title: Trump Tax Bill Holdouts Lured With SALT Hike, Medicaid Cuts
item.description: House Republican leaders released a new version of President Donald Trump’s massive tax and spending bill with a higher limit on the deduction for state and local taxes and other changes in a bid to win over warring GOP factions to support the legislation.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, Ari Natter, Erik Wasson, Emily Birnbaum

media:content.media:description: Mike Johnson Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: EU Sends New Trade Proposal to US in Step to Secure Deal
item.description: The European Union has shared a revised trade proposal with the US, as it aims to inject momentum in talks with President Donald Trump’s administration amid lingering skepticism that a transatlantic deal can be reached.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Containers at Trieste Port in Trieste, Italy.

item.title: Germany Says G-7 Finance Chiefs Agree Continued Ukraine Support
item.description: Finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrialized nations have agreed to continue backing Ukraine in its defense against Russia’s invasion, German Finance Minister Lars Klingbeil said on the sidelines of a G-7 meeting in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Lars Klingbeil during the G-7 finance ministers meeting in Banff, Canada. Photographer: Kay Nietfeld/dpa/AP Photo

item.title: Trump’s Research Funding Cuts Create Job Drought for Scientists
item.description: US job openings in research and development are plunging as the Trump administration ramps up funding cuts to government agencies, private contractors and universities, leaving some of the nation’s brightest minds scrambling to find work.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva, Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: New Zealand Targets Investment With Budget Tax Incentive
item.description: New Zealand’s government is introducing a new tax incentive to increase business investment as it seeks to lift productivity and stoke economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Withers

item.title: Kim Jong Un Slams ‘Serious’ Warship Accident at Launch Event
item.description: North Korea suffered a “serious accident” during the launch ceremony for a new destroyer, an event that was overseen by leader Kim Jong Un, the state-run Korean Central News Agency said.
item.dc:creator: Shinhye Kang, Seyoon Kim

media:content.media:description: In this photo provided by the North Korean government, Kim Jong Un, center, inspects the military exercises in North Korea on May 13.

item.title: Germany Scales Up Battle Tank Brigade in Baltics to Deter Russia
item.description: Germany is ramping up its battle tank brigade in Lithuania to strengthen NATO’s eastern flank as European allies take unprecedented steps to deter an increasingly hostile Russia.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber, Milda Seputyte

media:content.media:description: A German army Leopard 2 tank during a NATO exercise in Lithuania.

item.title: Japan’s Ishiba Calls for Closer Weapons Development With Allies
item.description: Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said Japan and its allies should deepen cooperation in the development of weapons and other defense equipment as threats mount across the Asia-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba

item.title: Judge Says US Deportations to South Sudan Violated His Order
item.description: A federal judge said the Trump administration violated his earlier order by sending eight migrants convicted of crimes to South Sudan, and he directed immediate action to protect their right to oppose deportation to a country gripped by years of violence.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell, Zoe Tillman, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JUNE 6: An ICE agent monitors hundreds of asylum seekers being processed upon entering the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building on June 6, 2023 in New York City. New York City has provided sanctuary to over 46,000 asylum seekers since 2013, when the city passed a law prohibiting city agencies from cooperating with federal immigration enforcement agencies unless there is a warrant for the person's arrest.(Photo by David Dee Delgado/Getty Images) Photographer: David Dee Delgado/Getty Images North America

item.title: Dueling US-China Videos Spark Pushback From Singapore Government
item.description: Singapore signaled displeasure at embassies attempting to evoke a public response, after the US and Chinese missions to the city-state posted dueling social media videos lashing out at one another on issues from the Panama Canal to the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans, Joanna Ossinger

media:content.media:description: The United States embassy in Singapore. Photographer: ROSLAN RAHMAN/AFP

item.title: Marcos Tells Cabinet to Quit, Seeking Reset After Midterms
item.description: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has told his entire Cabinet to resign, announcing a bid to “recalibrate” his administration after an underwhelming performance by his allies in last week’s Senate election.
item.dc:creator: Manolo Serapio Jr, Andreo Calonzo

media:content.media:description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. Photographer: Veejay Villafranca/Bloomberg

item.title: New Zealand Budget 2025: Winners and Losers
item.description: New Zealand Finance Minister Nicola Willis had billed Thursday’s budget as a sober affair that would contain “no unicorns, no rainbows.”
item.dc:creator: Ainsley Thomson

media:content.media:description: Nicola Willis Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

item.title: Bessent, Kato Confirm Existing FX Views, Avoid Talking Levels
item.description: US and Japanese finance chiefs confirmed existing currency views and did not discuss foreign exchange levels during a meeting in Canada, sending the yen briefly lower as markets wound back expectations for a more aggressive stance.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Bessent said he’s working with US legislators on outbound investment rules for China that would make clear what’s allowed and what’s not.

item.title: Trump Floats a Public Offering for Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac
item.description: President Donald Trump said Wednesday evening that he was giving “very serious consideration to bringing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac public” after more than a decade of being under government oversight.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Clark, Scott Carpenter, John Harney

media:content.media:description: Signage outside the Freddie Mac headquarters in Mclean, Virginia, US, on Tuesday, March 25, 2025. The head of the US Federal Housing Finance Agency on Tuesday ordered to end Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac programs intended to support first-time homebuyers by providing down payments and closing cost assistance. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: Hochul Digs In on Toll, Risking Federal Funds for NYC Projects
item.description: Transportation projects in Manhattan may be at risk of losing federal approval or funds after New York Governor Kathy Hochul rejected US Secretary of Transportation Sean Duffy’s demand to end congestion pricing or face potential consequences.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Kaske

media:content.media:description: Kathy Hochul on the uptown E train after a news conference on congestion pricing in New York on March 21.

item.title: House Republicans Scramble for Tax Deal Following Trump Meeting
item.description: House Republican leaders worked frantically Wednesday night to resolve divisions over Medicaid and green energy provisions in Donald Trump’s signature tax bill that threaten plans to vote on it this week.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Emily Birnbaum, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, and US House Speaker Mike Johnson, a Republican from Louisiana, arrive for a House Republican caucus meeting at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, May 20, 2025. Party leaders have been frantically negotiating with groups of lawmakers as House Speaker Mike Johnson strives to meet a self-imposed deadline of passing the package through the House before Congress goes on break for Memorial Day at the end of this week. Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Brazil Eases Environmental Rules Ahead of Key UN Climate Summit
item.description: Brazil’s lawmakers approved a measure to repair the country’s bureaucratic permitting process, drawing the ire of environmentalists who said the action dismantles key protections.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Carvalho

media:content.media:description: An aerial view of deforested land for cattle in Brazil. Photographer: Jonne Roriz/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Urges Cut to Russian Oil Price Cap at G-7 to Pressure Putin
item.description: The UK urged its Group of Seven allies to agree a cut to the price cap on Russian oil, saying the move is necessary to put further pressure on President Vladimir Putin to end Russia’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: In this pool photograph distributed by the Russian state agency Sputnik, Russian President Vladimir Putin looks on as he meets with students at the Sirius Educational Center in Sochi on May 19, 2025, after a telephone conversation with US President Donald Trump. (Photo by Alexander KAZAKOV / POOL / AFP) (Photo by ALEXANDER KAZAKOV/POOL/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Rice Costs Imperil Ishiba After Minister Quits in Japan
item.description: During Japan’s Edo period, feudal lords were warned that peasant revolts start with rice. Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba is finding political survival can still hinge on the price of the staple food.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama, Eddy Duan

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg
